en.paragraph1: Recently, while responding to job openings through a popular platform, in one of the dialogues, HR asked me a simple but important question:
en.paragraph2: ¬´Where can I see your actual projects, not just pictures on Dribbble?¬ª
en.paragraph3: At that moment it dawned on me: it was time to start a personal brand. Not just to post my work, but to create a space that tells who I am, what I do and how I think as a designer.
en.paragraph4: I wasn't looking to make another ‚Äúhere are the jobs, here are the contacts‚Äù template site. I wanted something more: a site that speaks, shows and feels like myself.
en.paragraph5: The goal was for anyone who visits the site to understand not only what I'm good at, but also how I approach problem solving.
en.paragraph6: I started by making a plan:
en.paragraph7: This plan became the foundation of the entire process. It helped to break down the project into steps, set priorities and keep the focus on what was important.
en.paragraph8: At the heart of everything is understanding who I'm making the site for. The Jobs To Be Done method helped: it focuses not on functions, but on the motivation of the user.
en.paragraph9: When I select a specialist, I want to see examples of their actual work, level of professionalism and thought process to see if they are a good fit for my particular task or team.
en.paragraph10: Building off of that, I went deeper - into the emotions, barriers, and expectations of the user.
en.paragraph11: I created an Empathy Map to understand how a person feels when they get to my site.
en.paragraph12: This helped me avoid blind spots and hone everything from pitch rhythm to micro-copywriting.
en.paragraph13: Next, I looked at how others were doing it - not to replicate it, but to see what worked and what didn't.
en.paragraph14: I drew three key conclusions from the analysis:
en.paragraph16: What should definitely be on the site.
en.paragraph17: What effect I want to evoke in the visitor.
en.paragraph18: To work more precisely with the content and interface, I created a User Persona - a notional image of the main visitor: an HR specialist.
en.paragraph19: I've articulated 5 scenarios in which the site should help:
en.paragraph20: ¬´When I open a portfolio, I want to understand who's in front of me and what their strengths are¬ª
en.paragraph22: ¬´I want to see not just pictures, but thinking¬ª
en.paragraph23: ‚Üí Solution: case structure - from task to result.
en.paragraph24: ¬´You need to figure out quickly if it's worth calling for an interview¬ª
en.paragraph25: ‚Üí Solution: a concise block of metrics and experience.
en.paragraph26: ¬´I want to get in touch right away¬ª
en.paragraph28: ¬´I'm watching from my phone - I want it to be convenient¬ª
en.paragraph29: ‚Üí Solution: adaptive design and clear hierarchy.
en.paragraph30: ¬´As a recruiter, I want to evaluate experience and cases to make the decision to recommend a candidate¬ª
en.paragraph31: ¬´As a designer, I want to be inspired, to see the approach, to compare thinking¬ª
en.paragraph32: These stories helped get me on the right wavelength - and not overcomplicate what should be simple.
en.paragraph33: I put everything together in a Customer Journey Map to see the journey through the eyes of the visitor.
en.paragraph35: Purpose: To understand who I am and how to contact me.
en.paragraph43: Site is slow to load ‚Üí goes away
en.paragraph44: Unclear structure ‚Üí does not find cases ‚Üí closes
en.paragraph46: User Flow showed where to simplify and where to add attention anchors.

en.paragraph49: Make communication as easy as possible.

en.paragraph67: Conducted live testing with a real user. I got feedback and made some adjustments.
en.paragraph68: I decided not to use frameworks. I wrote the code on pure HTML, CSS, JS - it gave me full control.
en.paragraph69: This project has been a real adventure for me - an experience of growth, self-discovery and skill development - rather than just building a website.
en.paragraph70: You can see its outcome right here, because this site itself is the result of the work done :)
en.paragraph71: New projects, new challenges and growth lay ahead. And this experience has become a solid foundation for my further professional path.
